title: Adding some species handler helpers

content.raw: This is copy/pasted from `periodic_table.py`
content.html: This is copy/pasted from periodic_table.py

content.raw: Of course I forgot about `D`, which is an isotope and not supported by this.  @brittonsmith , @ngoldbaum , @devinsilvia , do you think it should be implemented as a fake element in the periodic table?
content.html: Of course I forgot about D, which is an isotope and not supported by this. Britton Smith , Nathan Goldbaum , Devin Silvia , do you think it should be implemented as a fake element in the periodic table?

content.raw: I didn't see this information in the YTEP - does it need updated?
content.html: I didn't see this information in the YTEP - does it need updated?

content.raw: https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/ytep/pull-request/34/proposed-names-for-species-fields/diff
content.html: https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/ytep/pull-request/34/proposed-names-for-species-fields/diff

content.raw: (It's not accepted yet :))
content.html: (It's not accepted yet :))

content.raw: Thanks for the correct pointer :)
content.html: Thanks for the correct pointer :)

content.raw: D is common enough in astro that we should probably include it.  This also exposes the fact that we do not handle isotopes, but one thing at a time.
content.html: D is common enough in astro that we should probably include it. This also exposes the fact that we do not handle isotopes, but one thing at a time.

content.raw: So, does this now already work with Enzo's multispecies fields?  If so, can you provide an example of this?  Also, looks like there is a minor merger conflict.
content.html: So, does this now already work with Enzo's multispecies fields? If so, can you provide an example of this? Also, looks like there is a minor merger conflict.

content.raw: Never mind on the merger conflict.  Forgot to refresh the PR.
content.html: Never mind on the merger conflict. Forgot to refresh the PR.

content.raw:
Yup, it does.  Here's an example:

http://paste.yt-project.org/show/4383/
content.html:
Yup, it does. Here's an example:

http://paste.yt-project.org/show/4383/

content.raw: Maybe I missed the window to discuss this, but why "De" for the electron instead of "e" or "e_m1"?
content.html: Maybe I missed the window to discuss this, but why "De" for the electron instead of "e" or "e_m1"?

content.raw: Thanks, yes, this looks good.
content.html: Thanks, yes, this looks good.

content.raw: Ah, so that it was uniformly a capital initial letter.
content.html: Ah, so that it was uniformly a capital initial letter.

content.raw: Should the first number here be a 1 since D has atomic number 1?
content.html: Should the first number here be a 1 since D has atomic number 1?

content.raw: Ok, I see.  I'm not sure I understand specifically why "De," though.  Both "E" and "El" are also available.
content.html: Ok, I see. I'm not sure I understand specifically why "De," though. Both "E" and "El" are also available.

content.raw: I agree with that.  I don't know why I didn't use "El" but I like it better than "De".  I will update this PR and the YTEP.
content.html: I agree with that. I don't know why I didn't use "El" but I like it better than "De". I will update this PR and the YTEP.

content.raw: In principle, but I didn't want to overwrite the atomic number 1 for Hydrogen in that dictionary.  So I'm inclined to leave it as is.
content.html: In principle, but I didn't want to overwrite the atomic number 1 for Hydrogen in that dictionary. So I'm inclined to leave it as is.

content.raw: Ah, ok.  It wasn't clear to me how this structure was going to be accessed, so I didn't know if there would be any overwriting.
content.html: Ah, ok. It wasn't clear to me how this structure was going to be accessed, so I didn't know if there would be any overwriting.

content.raw: Ok, great.  I think De is an enzo-ism, since DeNum is the electron density field index.  Old habits die hard.
content.html: Ok, great. I think De is an enzo-ism, since DeNum is the electron density field index. Old habits die hard.

content.raw: Doesn't this need to be "El" too?
content.html: Doesn't this need to be "El" too?

content.raw: And if I'm understanding this right, wouldn't the 1.0 need to be changed to a very small value since it is not consistent with the a hydrogen mass?
content.html: And if I'm understanding this right, wouldn't the 1.0 need to be changed to a very small value since it is not consistent with the a hydrogen mass?

content.raw: Oh, hm, I actually want to get rid of this whole thing.  You're right about both, though.
content.html: Oh, hm, I actually want to get rid of this whole thing. You're right about both, though.

content.raw: Perhaps I'm being daft here, but shouldn't this get aliased to "El" consistent with the new species?
content.html: Perhaps I'm being daft here, but shouldn't this get aliased to "El" consistent with the new species?

content.raw: You're not being daft, this is actually one of the subtler points.  We want to preserve being able to access Enzo's `Electron_Density` field.  So we make it real.  But below, I add something that creates a derived field for `electron_density` that is the correct mass density.
content.html: You're not being daft, this is actually one of the subtler points. We want to preserve being able to access Enzo's Electron_Density field. So we make it real. But below, I add something that creates a derived field for electron_density that is the correct mass density.

content.raw: Er, `El_density`
content.html: Er, El_density

content.raw: I believe these are named Darmstadtium and Roentgenium respectively.
content.html: I believe these are named Darmstadtium and Roentgenium respectively.

content.raw: I see, so Electron_Density is in code units (like "Density", "code"), whereas El_Density is in physical units (like "density", "cgs") or however the new units system works?
content.html: I see, so Electron_Density is in code units (like "Density", "code"), whereas El_Density is in physical units (like "density", "cgs") or however the new units system works?

content.raw: @chummels since your comment disappeared now that I updated the PR, here is my response.  You are correct, yes.  And this is mentioned here: https://ytep.readthedocs.org/en/latest/YTEPs/YTEP-0003.html#molecular-and-atomic-species-names  but will be included in the docs under the enzo-specific "gotchas".
content.html: chummels since your comment disappeared now that I updated the PR, here is my response. You are correct, yes. And this is mentioned here: https://ytep.readthedocs.org/en/latest/YTEPs/YTEP-0003.html#molecular-and-atomic-species-names but will be included in the docs under the enzo-specific "gotchas".

content.raw: Any objections, or can we move ahead with this?
content.html: Any objections, or can we move ahead with this?

description:
This is the first step toward a better species system.  It includes a periodic table and a chemical formula parser.  The tests demonstrate some basic usage, but it is not really intended to be user-facing.

The next step will be implementing automatic species detection and creation of appropriate fields.

UPDATE 1: Adding chemical formula parser.

UPDATE 2: Adding species field plugin, using it for Enzo.

UPDATE 3: Missed one change.

UPDATE 4: To match my updated YTEP pull request, I have changed the electron specification to be De, and I've added D to the periodic table.  This is open for discussion.

UPDATE 5: Fixing conflict.

UPDATE 6: De => El

UPDATE 7: Removing `known_species_masses` function.
